page.title: 11WEYHILL HAWK CONSERVANCY.
page.content: Mr Smith's Hawk Conservancy has been in existence for six years and boasts 53 species of birds of prey from all parts of the world, the rarest being the merlin, the commonest the tawny owls and kestrels. Birds of prey are meat eaters, the hawks preferring rodents, the falcons liking other small birds and the vultures and kites being carrion feeders. To feed the birds the Conservancy buys half a tonne of meat weekly, taking up a big proportion of the Â£80 per day running costs. There are four aspects to Mr Smith's work: the protection, breeding and rearing of birds of prey; the caring for injured birds; the training of birds in the ancient art of falconry and, finally, the importance of recognising these birds in the wild & of conserving endangered species.
